awd_titl_txt: Quantifying Spin-Orbit Coupling in Rare-Earth Metals via Inverse Spin Hall Effect
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical description:
Rare earth metals and alloys are strategically important materials for several technologies that have significantly impacted society, including electric and hybrid vehicles, permanent magnets, catalysts, energy-efficient lightings, and lasers. The unique characteristics of rare earths arise from their electronic structure and properties. Understanding special aspects of these in rare-earth metals can provide guidance for future transformative technologies based on rare-earth materials. In addition, yttrium iron garnet (YIG) is an important magnetic material widely used in microwave applications such as telecommunication and radar technologies, and recently in spin pumping. The YIG films with state-of-the-art quality grown in the principal investigator's group improve the spin pumping efficiency and therefore the probability for future application of pure spin transport devices. The ability to produce top-quality materials is essential for enhancing the global competitiveness of the United States.  This project also includes an effort toward improving diversity in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics fields, including: advising an underrepresented minority student in the American Physical Society Bridge Program at the Ohio State University, promoting participation of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students in cutting-edge research, and building superconductor magnetic levitation experiments for a local high school in encouraging young students to pursue a career in the STEM fields.

Technical description:
The objective of this research project is to investigate the inverse spin Hall effect and spin-orbit coupling in the lanthanide rare-earth metals and understand the systematic behavior of spin Hall physics in this group of fundamentally intriguing and technologically important materials. One major focus of the spintronics field is the pursuit of materials with large spin Hall effect as characterized by the spin Hall angle. This has led to quantitative determination of spin Hall angles in a broad range of materials, including the systematic measurements on the 3d and 5d transition metals by the principle investigator?s group. In fact, transition metals exhibits some of the largest spin Hall angles due to the large orbital moment of the d electrons, which points toward the possibility of finding even larger spin Hall effect in rare-earth metals due to their giant f-orbital moments and large atomic numbers as predicted by theory. However, the spin Hall effect in rare-earth metals is essentially unexplored to date. Ferromagnetic resonance spin pumping of pure spin currents from YIG thin films into metals is a versatile and reliable technique for characterizing the inverse spin Hall effect and extracting spin Hall angle. This project has the following goals: (1) understand the intrinsic inverse spin Hall effect in pure lanthanide rare-earth metals and uncover the role of 4f electrons in spin Hall effect; (2) investigate the extrinsic inverse spin Hall effect arising from rare-earth impurities in copper and gold; (3) characterize the interfacial spin conductances between the rare earth metals and other materials to understand spin transfer efficiency across interfaces. The expected outcome of this research is the systematic and quantitative understanding of the spin Hall physics in rare earth metals, which, in principle, possess all the attributes for the emergence of exceptionally large spin Hall effect.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this NSF project is to systematically investigate the novel magnetic and spin-electronic phenomena enabled by the spin-orbit coupling (SOC) in thin film heterostructures involving rare-earth materials and compounds.  Building on a unique off-axis sputter deposition technique developed in the PI?s lab, the PI?s group grows high quality single-crystalline films of a wide range of materials and quantitatively studies the magnetic and dynamic spin transport behavior in these structures using a variety of cutting-edge techniques.  

This NSF grant has led to 14 peer-reviewed publications, some of which are in prestigious journals such as Physical Review Letters, Advanced Materials, and Nature Communications.  The main project outcomes include:

1. Growth of highly quality single-crystalline epitaxial Co25Fe75 films and observation of ultralow magnetic damping down to 7 x 10-4 at microwave frequencies.  This record-low magnetic damping in metallic ferromagnetic thin films is highly desirable for charge-based spin-electronic device applications due to their low loss and high energy efficiency.  Through systematically investigation of the angular dependent ferromagnetic resonance of various thicknesses of the Co25Fe75 epitaxial films, the PI?s group identifies the three types of contributions to the magnetic damping, which leads to the fundamental understanding of the damping mechanisms in these promising metallic ferromagnetic films.

2. Control of spin currents in bilayer graphene on ferrimagnetic insulator Y3Fe5O12 (YIG) epitaxial films by atomic-scale proximity interaction at the interface.  Two-dimensional (2D) materials provide a unique platform to explore the full potential of magnetic proximity driven phenomena, which can be used for applications in next generation spin-electronic devices.  The PI?s group and collaborators investigated magnetic proximity induced modulation of spin currents in bilayer graphene on YIG films.  A small in-plane magnetic field applied at different angle can tune the spin currents in graphene to achieve complete spin modulation, demonstrating the capability of controlling the spin flow in low-dimensional materials.

3. Robust magnetic skyrmion formation in FeGe epitaxial thin films without the need of an external magnetic field.  Magnetic skyrmions are topological spin textures which have attracted significant interests in recent years due to their intriguing magnetic interactions and attractive attributes for spin-electronic applications.  We grew FeGe epitaxial films of pure B20 phase which is required for harboring skyrmions.  The FeGe films exhibit strong topological Hall resistivity in a broad temperature range with significant remanent values at zero magnetic field, demonstrating robust skyrmion formation without the need of an external magnetic field, which is desired for technological applications.

4. Thickness dependence of spin Hall angle of gold layers on YIG epitaxial films.  Spin Hall angle is directly related to the spin-orbit coupling and quantitatively describes the ability of a material to convert an unpolarized electrical current to a spin current, and vice versa.  One intriguing question in the research field is whether the spin Hall angle of a heavy metal (such as gold) varies with the film thickness.  To address this question, PI?s group investigated the thickness dependence of the spin Hall angle of gold layers of various thicknesses between 5 and 100 nm on YIG.  The 50 and 100 nm samples have sizable spin Hall angle of 0.016 and 0.017, respectively, which is reasonable for a heavy element like gold.  In comparison, the 5 nm sample has an even larger spin Hall angle of 0.087.  The large spin Hall angle for the 5 nm gold film is likely due to its high resistivity and the gold/air interface which may contribute a Rashba-type spin-orbit coupling.

5. Imaging magnetization structure and dynamics in YIG/Pt bilayers using time-resolved longitudinal spin Seebeck effect.  The PI?s group and collaborators studied the magnetization state and dynamics of thin YIG/Pt bilayers using time-resolved longitudinal spin Seebeck effect microscopy, where a picosecond laser was focused on the YIG film to generate thermally driven spin current from the YIG into the Pt by the spin Seebeck effect.  The spin current was then detected using the inverse spin Hall effect induced transverse voltage in the Pt layer.  The pulsed optical heating generates a magnetization-dependent voltage pulse of less than 100 picosecond, demonstrating the capability of this technique in imaging both static magnetic structure and Gigahertz-frequency magnetic resonance dynamics with sub-micrometer spatial resolution and high sensitivity to magnetic orientation in thin YIG films.
